content.description: Easy route that just takes advantage of the natural hand and footholds up the face. A little bit in the way of acrobatics may be required, but nothing too insane. Short, sweet route, perfect for beginners (my ex-girlfriend climbed it the first time that she ever climbed).
content.protection: Anchor off tree for top rope or slingshot top rope.
content.location: There's a small debris pile against the base of the cliff. start from the top of this and just follow obvious hand holds. As of right now, this route requires some cleaning. Just rappel back to the bottom.

content.description: Crack to the left of Perry-noia that is pretty much a finger crack in a little dihedral. Tightens as it gets to the top. A little wet, but overall doesn't affect the grip. Very small footholds/smearing. Nothing insane, but some little fun.
content.protection: Top Rope off tree at the top of the route
content.location: Next to the rockfall pile, to the left of Perry-noia, away from the little trees on the face. Climb, rappel, or be lowered down.

content.description: Shaded wall about half a mile downstream on the trail from the park proper (it's still inside the park though, so there are no access issues). About 35 foot high wall, with a fairly blank, less than vertical face. Good for slingshot top roping, all though scrambling to the top is an adventure in and of its self. Your best bet is climbing up on the left end of the cliff where a few trees grow up the side. For the most part, it's very good solid sandstone but has some shale underneath the overhang. Overall just a fun little place to play around. Takes a long time to dry however.
